title: Arnold Schwarzenegger enjoys a cigar after an evening at Annabel's in Mayfair
text:
Arnold Schwarzenegger looked dapper as he enjoyed a cigar after a night out at Annabel's in Mayfair, London, on Friday night.

The Hollywood A-lister, 72, put on a stylish display in a crisp white unbuttoned shirt and a smart blue blazer for his fun evening in the British capital.

The Predator star added a pair of blue jeans to his ensemble, a black belt with an oversized gold buckle and suede shoes.

Dapper: Arnold Schwarzenegger looked dapper as he enjoyed a cigar after a night out at Annabel's in Mayfair, London, on Friday night

The former champion bodybuilder, who made a return to acting after leaving his post as governor of California in 2011, looked pleased to be in London as he smiled for photographers.

His appearance comes as he appears on the big screen once more alongside his Terminator co-star Linda Hamilton, 63.

The pair are both making a return to the long-running franchise in Terminator: Dark Fate, which is set to be released next month.

Stylish: The Hollywood A-lister, 72, put on a stylish display in a crisp white unbuttoned shirt and a smart blue blazer for his fun evening in the British capital

Turning heads: The Predator star added a pair of blue jeans to his ensemble, a black belt with an oversized gold buckle and suede shoes

They appeared together on the BBC's Graham Norton Show on Friday night, where Arnold revealed that he's 'disappointed' that he can't run for President of the United States of America.

And while the former California Governor mused about his politics, Linda revealed that she and her ex-husband James Cameron 'don't talk at all' - despite the Canadian filmmaker directing the latest Terminator instalment.

Arnold said: 'I hate politics. Even when I was Governor (of California) I never considered myself a politician.

Happy: The former champion bodybuilder, who made a return to acting after leaving his post as governor of California in 2011, looked pleased to be in London as he smiled for photographers

Exciting: His appearance comes as he appears on the big screen once more alongside his Terminator co-star Linda Hamilton, 63

'I was a public servant who created policies to make things better for people.'

Asked if he's disappointed that, because he is Austrian he can't run for president, he said: 'Of course. It would have been great to jump in and run.

'It's the only thing I can't do in America. Everything else I've done is because it is in America, it's the land of opportunity.'

Turning his attention to Linda, Graham asked how she was persuaded by James Cameron, her ex-husband and director of the new movie, to reprise the role.

Linda revealed: 'We don't talk at all. He rang three times and it was only on the third call when he mentioned it was about work that I rang him back!

'It took me a little while to decide if I had something more to do with her character.'

Candid: It comes after Anorld revealed he's 'disappointed' that he can't run for President (pictured with Linda Hamilton) on The Graham Norton Show on Friday night

Revealing that she'd had to be persuaded to do the very first Terminator, Linda said: 'I didn't want to do it at all. I was a snotty New York actress and I didn't want to go to California.

'It was only when I saw Arnie on set and he was fantastic, that I thought, "I'm in!"

Arnold, a little crestfallen, asked: 'You didn't want to work with me? That's the first time I've heard that story.'

Linda divorced Terminator director James in 1999 after two years of marriage. The former couple share daughter Josephine, 26.
